tweets.text: @JamesBevanEA @EnvAgencyMids hope you‚Äôve enjoyed a lovely weekend . All that lovely fresh air , well just to keep you updated we‚Äôve had our regular doses of HYDROGEN SULFIDE  here in Newcastle under Lyme . All thanks to you and your good friends at red Industries .@StinkStopthe

They drain our chalk streams dry, dump over 3.1 million hours worth of sewage into our rivers and now this.

The water industry is the UKs' largest source of micro plastic pollution in rivers.

So much for regulation then. @Defra @Ofwat @EnvAgency 

https://t.co/Sb77dX1RmG

@timthefruit @FriendsUpperWye @MerryAlbright @GValleyAG2 @DaveThroupEA @EllieChowns @Jamesxparsons @watsonchas @Feargal_Sharkey @Marc_Willimont @HelenStace_HWT @SaveTheWye @EnvAgency It is already happening in Herefordshire and about to be expanded by several hundred % #hope

Reminding you your promises to Punjab @capt_amarinder. You promised to improve tree cover in 2017 but now you are getting 136 Acres deforested in Faridkot. Are you bent on breaking all your promises to Punjab? Shameful. https://t.co/ymalvAPbze

entity.name: Countryfile
entity.description: Stories are shared of the people, places and issues at the heart of the British countryside. Popular features include the programme's photography contest, which culminates in a yearly calendar sold to benefit charity, the Video Diary, produced by viewers and focused on life in rural areas, and the weather forecasts.

domain.name: TV Shows
domain.description: Television shows from around the world

entity.name: Countryfile Diaries
entity.description: A sister show to the BBC's `Countryfile' series, this rural affairs programme sees a team of presenters travel the length and breadth of the United Kingdom to cover stories related to the British countryside and the season of spring. As this period is a busy time of the year for the farming and outdoor communities in particular, regular topics covered include the production of food, nature conservation, and a look at a chosen area's culture and history. Stunning landscapes and a variety of wildlife also feature prominently.

tweets.text: @bettwsresident @FriendsUpperWye @MerryAlbright @GValleyAG2 @DaveThroupEA @EllieChowns @Jamesxparsons @watsonchas @Feargal_Sharkey @Marc_Willimont @HelenStace_HWT @SaveTheWye I agree that WPZ would be a big step in the right direction but will still need enforcement by @EnvAgency and look where we are with that!

@defra we really need you to sort out Walleys Quarry , @EnvAgency have not done so , the tail is wagging the dog over this issue . We've been fobbed off enough now , please get this festering ,rancid , gas producing hell hole closed down . @StinkStopthe

Not only that but the estimated % of pollution source varies across counties e.g. in Somerset it's more of a 50/50 split between diffuse agricultural pollution and wastewater. But has @NaturalEngland fingered the wrong perp at large?

@Vincent9Helen @MattHancock @PHE_uk @PHE_WestMids @DefraGovUK @RCObsGyn @StinkStopthe @EnvAgencyMids I'll second that , not many trust @EnvAgencyMids due to their  constant procrastinating over action against the perpetrators of the gas .

urls.title: Water firms are main source of microplastics in UK rivers, study says
urls.description: Research says discharge of untreated sewage and wastewater during dry spells to blame

tweets.text:
Important new research out today by @Jamie_Woodward_ & others identifies water firms as the main source of microplastics in UK rivers. 

Builds more pressure on government @EnvAgency to tackle the way water firms release untreated effluent into our rivers.
https://t.co/HKK1Ar0abP

tweets.text: An assessment by @EnvAgency of the Wye, estimates the chief source of pollution (~60%+) is agricultural and waste water from existing homes (~25%). Sustainable house builder @MerryAlbright has estimated new homes on the Wye contribute less than 1% of phosphate loading.
